comment.author: 42264328@N00
comment._content: Looks to be SS Imperator: SS Imperator was an ocean liner built for the Hamburg America Line (German: Hamburg-Amerikanische Packetfahrt-Actien-Gesellschaft or HAPAG) launched in 1912. You can see the same figurehead on the photo in the Wikipedia article.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The NYT of June 20, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=990DE5DE113BE633A... reported that: "IMPERATOR MINDS HELM LIKE A YACHT; Cheered by Thousands Afloat and Ashore She Gracefully Swims Into Her Berth. The largest ship afloat, the 50,000-ton Imperator, steamed majestically up the harbor from Quarantine yesterday forenoon to her pier in Hoboken and docked with the aid of eleven tugs and her own powerful propellers in forty-five minutes." Two days later, query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=940CE1DE113BE633A... a piece described her luxury and included a picture of the figurehead.

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: cotinis and swang:  Thanks for your information about the SS Imperator its figurehead, and the interesting NYT articles.  We will update our source data and reload the description.

comment._content: This appears to be a photo of the figurehead on a model, rather than on the actual ship.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: It is a model, the figurehead itself bore the inscription "MEIN FELD IST DIE WELT", see

comment.author: 63860770@N07
comment._content: Maritime Texas, I believe you are correct. This does appear to be a model. The Bain collection has another photo of the model Imperator that hasn't made it to Flickr yet at www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ggb2005013229/. I'll ask to add that to the the catalog record.
